awd_titl_txt: Planning: CRISES: Center for Urban Climate Adaptation Solutions
awd_abstract_narration:
Cities concentrate people, wealth, and infrastructure, and, as a result, cities concentrate vulnerability to the growing risks posed by climate change. People who are already socially and/or economically marginalized, such as members of communities of color, families living in poverty, and the elderly, are particularly vulnerable to climate risks. In many cities, this is compounded by rising income inequality and unequal access to urban infrastructure and services. While researchers and city leaders are increasingly aware of the need to build more climate resilient cities, the project focuses on building collaborative relationships and the preparatory work to propose a new Center for Urban Climate Adaptation Solutions (CUCAS), which brings together urban experts in multiple disciplines and institutions, works closely with civil society and public sector stakeholders, and uses New York City as the project’s urban laboratory. The significance of the new Center is in its inclusive, holistic, transdisciplinary, and deeply engaged approach to the complexity of understanding climate change hazards as well as a platform where citizens actively participate in shaping responses to climate change. 

Cities are increasingly experiencing the effects of climate change impacts, such as rising temperatures, changing precipitation patterns, and sea-level rise, as well as extreme weather events. The project inventories existing data and data needs, maps civil society and institutional capacities, and conducts a needs assessment in three core research areas: 1) a citywide spatial assessment of multi-hazard climate change risks from coastal and pluvial flooding, extreme heat, and air quality; 2) a citywide assessment of socioeconomic factors that affect climate vulnerabilities, as well as civic and public capacities to respond to climate change; and 3) an exploration of the potential for new urban data technologies to support more efficient and equitable climate change responses. By combining diverse sources of data and knowledge, including collaboration with civil society partners, the project explores if it is possible to co-design more effective, contextually appropriate responses to climate change hazards. Based on the work in these three research areas, the project conceptualizes a new Center for Urban Climate Adaptation Solutions (CUCAS), to serve as a critical research and knowledge hub for New York City, other U.S. cities, and beyond, as well as to act as a training center for the next generation of urban climate change researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes

Cities concentrate people, infrastructure, and wealth—but also vulnerability to climate change risks, with disproportionate impacts on those who are already socially and economically marginalized. City leaders increasingly recognize the need to adapt; what is still missing in most cities is an inclusive, holistic approach that captures the complexity of climate risks and enables citizens to actively shape equitable responses.

The proposed Civic-Led Urban Adaptation Research Center (CIVIC-UARC) aims to provide that for New York City. Through interdisciplinary and transdisciplinary research, CIVIC-UARC will generate new knowledge that can be used in New York and other U.S. cities that are grappling with climate change in the context of rising inequality and a legacy of environmental injustice. It will also educate and train a new generation of scientific investigators, change agents, and decision-makers working on urban climate change adaptation.

For more than a year, the project team engaged with diverse stakeholders to further develop the CIVIC-UARC concept, taking a “coproduction” approach to urban adaptation research and action, with special attention to environmental justice. The work brought together urban experts across multiple disciplines and institutions, civil society organizations, and communities, focusing mainly on heat, flooding, and air quality. The discussions included key government agencies in New York City, as well as representatives from private industry. The discussions were framed around three research areas:

1. Adapting to multiple and cascading climate risks

Effective, equitable, and timely adaptation planning requires a nuanced understanding of the hazards and risks associated with climate change. This research area focuses on improving our understanding of how climate hazards are spatially distributed and how human activity, the built environment, and natural processes interact. It gives special attention to how climate risks compound and cascade.

2. Climate change vulnerability and community capacity for adaptation

An understanding of underlying community vulnerabilities and capacities to respond to emerging climate risks is necessary for the equitable and effective allocation of climate adaptation resources. To support more just climate investment outcomes, the project team seeks to understand household and community and climate vulnerabilities and capacities in underserved neighborhoods of NYC.

3. Developing a ‘digital twin’ of New York City to support adaptation

Rapidly evolving digital technologies have the potential to support more coordinated and participatory emergency response and long-term planning. The aim of this research area is to create an open computational platform for decision-makers in the public and private sectors, researchers, civil society, and the general public to better understand climate-related issues, evaluate potential responses, and engage in scenario planning.

Intellectual Merit

The work produced valuable findings and identified several critical knowledge gaps, including:

  • There is a lack of understanding about how multiple climate change hazards compound and cascade to create new risks in urban settings like New York City.
  • Critical data for responding to climate change hazards in New York City is siloed in city departments, though officials are interested in finding new ways to share data and coordinate.
  • Inadequate communication and knowledge-sharing between city government and communities limits the effectiveness of emergency response, as well as longer term planning and interventions.
  • New York City’s physical infrastructure systems (transportation, energy, water, and waste) are unsuited to the changing climate. Research and innovation are needed to retrofit existing infrastructure and ensure that new infrastructure is more resilient to future climate change.  
  • Historical patterns of unequal public investment in New York City have exacerbated social vulnerability and exposure to climate hazards.
  • Vulnerability indices provide useful information, but lack sufficient granular detail to capture complex local dynamics. They can be improved by incorporating local knowledge about how impacts are experienced, key vulnerabilities, and social networks.
  • More research is needed on the mechanisms by which communities respond to climate hazards, and how government agencies can best support them.
  • New York City lacks basic data about the built environment (i.e., updated base map, LIDAR data, build footprints, and building heights) that is critical to emergency response and longer-term planning.
  • More analysis is needed on how best to integrate and automate relevant demographic, socio-economic, built environment, biophysical datasets in a safe and “user friendly” format for all stakeholders.

Broader Impacts

Looking ahead, the CIVIC-UARC project team aims to support New York and other cities to create a more equitable, sustainable, and climate-resilient urban environment, including both physical and social infrastructure systems. Planned future research includes:

  • Enhanced decision-making on how to retrofit existing systems of legacy infrastructure, build climate-resilient new infrastructure, and support community-based social infrastructure systems;
  • Shaping public climate investments to address historical legacies of environmental injustice;
  • Improving public understanding of climate risks, vulnerability, and adaptation;
  • Building a computational platform capable of real-time, automated collection of currently disparate datasets, to serve as the basis for a “digital twin” of New York City.
  • Coproduce a comprehensive climate resilience plan for the city.
